items.title: Gaza’s Rafah border crossing with Egypt reopens for limited travel – latest updates
items.standfirst: Rafah crossing in the south, which has largely been closed since May 2024, has reopened for those travelling on footMore than 400 European former top diplomats and officials have urged the EU to increase pressure on Israel to end “excesses and unremitting violations of international law” over Gaza and the West Bank.The statement, due to be sent to EU leaders on Monday, calls on the bloc and its member states to take action in line with its support for a UN resolution for a two-state solution and a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. Continue reading...
items.content: Rafah crossing in the south, which has largely been closed since May 2024, has reopened for those travelling on footMore than 400 European former top diplomats and officials have urged the EU to increase pressure on Israel to end “excesses and unremitting violations of international law” over Gaza and the West Bank.The statement, due to be sent to EU leaders on Monday, calls on the bloc and its member states to take action in line with its support for a UN resolution for a two-state solution and a just and lasting peace in the Middle East. items.title: Gaza's Rafah crossing makes limited reopening after two-year war
items.standfirst: Gaza’s Rafah border crossing has partially reopened, allowing limited movement of Palestinians after months of closure. Israeli officials confirmed the reopening, while Egyptian media said only 50 people per direction will be permitted initially. The move follows Israel’s seizure of the crossing in May 2024 and comes after pressure from aid groups, with operations resuming in a tightly restricted pilot phase. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.
items.content: Gaza’s Rafah border crossing has partially reopened, allowing limited movement of Palestinians after months of closure. Israeli officials confirmed the reopening, while Egyptian media said only 50 people per direction will be permitted initially. The move follows Israel’s seizure of the crossing in May 2024 and comes after pressure from aid groups, with operations resuming in a tightly restricted pilot phase. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.

items.title: Gaza’s Rafah crossing to reopen for Palestinians on Monday, Israel says
items.standfirst: Officials say Gaza residents travelling on foot only will be allowed through border point, which was shut in May 2024Gaza’s main border crossing in Rafah will reopen for Palestinians on Monday, Israel has said, with preparations under way at the war-ravaged territory’s gateway, which has been mostly closed for almost two years.Before the war, the Rafah crossing with Egypt was the only direct exit point for most Palestinians in Gaza to reach the outside world as well as a key entry point for aid. It has been largely shut since May 2024. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: A five-year-old boy whose detention in the Trump administration's aggressive immigration raids in Minneapolis shocked the world returned to Minnesota, a lawmaker said Sunday. Liam Conejo Ramos and his father, Adrian Conejo Arias, were detained in a Minneapolis suburb on January 20 and held at an ICE facility in Texas before their release.

items.title: Plunge in price of gold and silver rattles global stock markets
items.standfirst: Trump’s pick of ‘respected central banker’ Kevin Warsh as Fed chair seen as catalyst for sell-off as investors sell safe haven assetsBusiness news – live updatesGold and silver prices have plunged, as a “meltdown” in the metals market deepened and rattled stock exchanges around the world.Gold prices tumbled by 8% to $4,465 an ounce on Monday, ending a run of record highs that took it to nearly $5,600 just last week, before recovering some ground. Silver fell by 7%, after a 30% slump on Friday. Continue reading...

Silver fell by 7%, after a 30% slump on Friday. Continue reading...

items.title: Gold, silver continue to fall as record rally runs out of road
items.standfirst: Precious metals continued to lose ground this Monday following steep declines last week, with investors piling out of the safe haven assets after US President Donald Trump picked Kevin Warsh to lead the Federal Reserve. Also in this edition: French tech giant Capgemini plans to sell off the US subsidiary that provides immigrant tracking data to ICE.
items.content: Precious metals continued to lose ground this Monday following steep declines last week, with investors piling out of the safe haven assets after US President Donald Trump picked Kevin Warsh to lead the Federal Reserve. items.title: Oracle to Raise Up to $50 Billion for Cloud Investment
items.standfirst: Oracle Corp. plans to raise $45 billion to $50 billion this year through a combination of debt and equity sales. The company is raising money to build additional capacity to meet the contracted demand from the its largest cloud customers, including Nvidia Corp. and OpenAI. items.title: Odd Lots: The Data Center Demand Story Doesn’t Add Up (Podcast)
items.standfirst: Utilities analysts are having a moment as the energy sector gets a boost from AI. With an extra 94 gigawatts forecast to be needed by 2030 to power all these new data centers, energy investment has become a hot play as investors take a “picks and shovels” approach. But one long-time analyst says that — from a utilities perspective — we’re already set to overbuild capacity by twice as much as is needed. On this episode, Andy DeVries, co-head of investment grade credit and head of utilities and po

clusters.title: UK’s ex-ambassador Mandelson quits Labour over Epstein links, reports say
clusters.neutral_headline: UK’s ex-ambassador Mandelson quits Labour over Epstein links, reports say

items.title: UK’s ex-ambassador Mandelson quits Labour over Epstein links, reports say
items.standfirst: Peter Mandelson says he is stepping down to avoid causing further embarrassment to governing party.
items.content: Peter Mandelson says he is stepping down to avoid causing further embarrassment to governing party.

items.title: UK’s Peter Mandelson resigns from Labour party after Epstein ties resurface
items.standfirst: Former British ambassador to Washington Peter Mandelson quit the Labour Party on Sunday after newly released US documents revived scrutiny of his links to late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Mandelson said he wanted to avoid causing “further embarrassment” and denied wrongdoing.
items.content: Former British ambassador to Washington Peter Mandelson quit the Labour Party on Sunday after newly released US documents revived scrutiny of his links to late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Mandelson said he wanted to avoid causing “further embarrassment” and denied wrongdoing.

ai_summary: Peter Mandelson quits Labour party
Epstein links prompted resignation
Mandelson denies wrongdoing
Resignation aims to avoid embarrassment
Labour party faces scrutiny over links
